channel.title: A possible base for a bot
channel.description:
Alright, krypton and i have long since abandoned the idea of making a bot because we are both lazy and cant see the point of it much anymore, many of my ideas have changed since we stopped
the system would work in three parts, it can be considered similar to arga; the updater, the slave and the master. though early plans were to update on runtime, but was abandoned due to it not having enough benifits
the updater would download the jar, insert any accessors + interfaces and override/patch and "undesirable" methods. after this, it would then be dumped as a custom formatted file containing information on the classes and their raw bytes
the slave itself would be based around a java agent. it loads the binary file, parses it, then as classes are loaded the byte arrays are swapped into place of the current class being loaded
the master would be the front end for all slaves, possibly even on other machines. it would be a console-styled interface, accepting commands to control the slaves and dispatching the commands using RMI
nothing done so far in the area of input, though its rather obvious what you have to do
ill attach what little we have for the sake of learning from other peoples mistakes :D you may have to fix some of the imports, as i slapped this together from two different projects

item.title: A possible base for a bot
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

A reflection explorer, just have to add in array’s lol

import impsoft.nexus.bots.color.methods.ColorScript;
import impsoft.nexus.gui.GuiThread;

import java.lang.reflect.Field;

import org.eclipse.swt.SWT;
import org.eclipse.swt.events.SelectionEvent;
import org.eclipse.swt.events.SelectionListener;
import org.eclipse.swt.layout.FillLayout;
import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Composite;
import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Shell;
import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Table;
import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.TableColumn;
import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.TableItem;

public class ReflectionExplorer extends ColorScript {

	public boolean doStart(String cmd, String[] args)
			throws InterruptedException {
		return true;
	}

	public void script() throws InterruptedException {
		GuiThread.theDisplay.asyncExec(new Runnable(){
			public void run() {
				makeGui(theBot.theApplet);
			}
		});
	}

	public void makeGui(Object o) {
		if (o == null) {
			return;
		}
		Shell shell = new Shell(GuiThread.theDisplay);
		shell.setText("Explorer for " + o);
		shell.setLayout(new FillLayout());
		final Composite composite = new Composite(shell, SWT.NONE);
		composite.setLayout(new FillLayout());
		final Table table = new Table(composite, SWT.FULL_SELECTION
				| SWT.BORDER);
		table.setLinesVisible(true);
		table.setHeaderVisible(true);
		TableColumn newColumnTableColumn1 = new TableColumn(table, SWT.NONE);
		newColumnTableColumn1.setWidth(100);
		newColumnTableColumn1.setText("name");
		TableColumn newColumnTableColumn2 = new TableColumn(table, SWT.NONE);
		newColumnTableColumn2.setWidth(200);
		newColumnTableColumn2.setText("type");
		TableColumn newColumnTableColumn3 = new TableColumn(table, SWT.NONE);
		newColumnTableColumn3.setWidth(300);
		newColumnTableColumn3.setText("value");
		final Field fields[] = o.getClass().getDeclaredFields();
		final Object FieldObjects[]= new Object[fields.length];
		for(int i=0;i<fields.length;i++){
			fields[i].setAccessible(true);
			FieldObjects[i]=fieldObject(fields[i], o);
			fields[i].setAccessible(false);
		}
		for (Field field : fields) {
			
			field.setAccessible(true);
			
			String name = field.getName();
			String type = field.getType().toString();
			String value = fieldValue(field, o);
			TableItem newItemTableItem = new TableItem(table,
                    SWT.BORDER);
            newItemTableItem.setText(0, name);
            newItemTableItem.setText(1, type);
            newItemTableItem.setText(2, value);
			field.setAccessible(false);
		}
		table.addSelectionListener(new SelectionListener(){

			public void widgetDefaultSelected(SelectionEvent arg0) {}

			public void widgetSelected(SelectionEvent e) {
				try{
					makeGui(FieldObjects[table.getSelectionIndex()]);
				} catch (Exception k) {
					exception(k);
				}
			}
			
		});
		shell.pack();
		GuiThread.center(GuiThread.theShell.getBounds(), shell);
		shell.open();
	}
	public Object fieldObject(Field theField, Object theObject){
		Class typeClass = theField.getType();
		String fieldType = typeClass.getName();
		if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("boolean")) {

		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("int")) {

		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("double")) {

		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("long")) {

		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("byte")) {

		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("char")) {

		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("float")) {

		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("short")) {

		} else if(typeClass.isArray()){
			try {
				//TODO
			} catch (Exception e) {
				exception(e);
			}
		} else {
			try {
				if (theField != null) {
					Object x = theField.get(theObject);
					return x;
				}
			} catch (Exception e) {
				exception(e);
			}
		}
		return null;
	}
	public String fieldValue(Field theField, Object theObject) {

		Class typeClass = theField.getType();
		String fieldType = typeClass.getName();
		if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("boolean")) {
			try {
				if (theField != null) {
					boolean x = theField.getBoolean(theObject);
					return "" + x;
				}
			} catch (Exception e) {
				exception(e);
			}
		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("int")) {
			try {
				if (theField != null) {
					int x = theField.getInt(theObject);
					return " " + x;
				}
			} catch (Exception e) {
				exception(e);
			}
		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("double")) {
			try {
				if (theField != null) {
					double x = theField.getDouble(theObject);
					return "" + x;
				}
			} catch (Exception e) {
				exception(e);
			}
		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("long")) {
			try {
				if (theField != null) {
					long x = theField.getLong(theObject);
					return "" + x;
				}
			} catch (Exception e) {
				exception(e);
			}
		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("byte")) {
			try {
				if (theField != null) {
					byte x = theField.getByte(theObject);
					return "" + x;
				}
			} catch (Exception e) {
				exception(e);
			}
		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("char")) {
			try {
				if (theField != null) {
					char x = theField.getChar(theObject);
					return "" + x;
				}
			} catch (Exception e) {
				exception(e);
			}
		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("float")) {
			try {
				if (theField != null) {
					float x = theField.getFloat(theObject);
					return "" + x;
				}
			} catch (Exception e) {
				exception(e);
			}
		} else if (fieldType.equalsIgnoreCase("short")) {
			try {
				if (theField != null) {
					short x = theField.getShort(theObject);
					return "" + x;
				}
			} catch (Exception e) {
				exception(e);
			}
		} else if(typeClass.isArray()){
			try {
				Class componentClass = typeClass.getComponentType();
				String componentName = componentClass.getName();
				String printOut = "";
				while (componentClass.isArray()) {
					componentClass = componentClass.getComponentType();
					printOut += "[]";
				}
				return componentName+printOut;
			} catch (Exception e) {
				exception(e);
			}
		} else {
			try {
				if (theField != null) {
					Object x = theField.get(theObject);
					if (x != null) {
						return x.toString();
					} else {
						return "null";
					}
				}
			} catch (Exception e) {
				exception(e);
			}
		}
		return "";
	}

}

item.title: A possible base for a bot
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

package bot.update.transformer;

import com.sun.org.apache.bcel.internal.classfile.Field;
import com.sun.org.apache.bcel.internal.classfile.JavaClass;
import com.sun.org.apache.bcel.internal.classfile.Method;
import com.sun.org.apache.bcel.internal.generic.*;

import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileNotFoundException;
import java.io.PrintStream;
import java.util.Iterator;

/**
 * Created by IntelliJ IDEA.
 * User: Silab
 * Date: Feb 25, 2007
 * Time: 2:21:47 AM
 * Project: bot.update.transformer
 */
public class nonstatic extends Transformer {
    PrintStream ps;

    public nonstatic() {
        new File("client info").mkdir();
    }

    public boolean find(JavaClass clazz) {
        int i = 0;
        int j = 0;
        try {
            ps = new PrintStream(new File("client info//" + clazz.getClassName() + ".txt"));
        } catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
        ps.println("Class Name: " + clazz.getClassName());
        ps.println("Class isAbstract: " + clazz.isAbstract()+"\n\n");
        for (Field f : clazz.getFields()) {
            if (!f.isStatic()) {
                ps.println("Field Name: " + f.getName());
                ps.println("Field Type: " + f.getType()+"\n\n");
                i++;
            }

        }
        for (Method m : clazz.getMethods()) {
            if (!m.isStatic()) {
                ps.println("Method Name: " + m.getName());
                ps.println("Method Number of Args: " + m.getArgumentTypes().length);
                if (m.getArgumentTypes().length > 0) {
                    Type[] types = m.getArgumentTypes();
                    for (int x = 0; x < m.getArgumentTypes().length; x++)
                        ps.println("\t Arg[" + x + "]: " + types[x]);
                }
                ps.println("\n");
                j++;
            }

        ps.println("\n\n");
        ps.println("Total non-static fields: " + i);
        ps.println("Total non-static methods: " + j);
        ps.close();
        }
        return false;
    }

    public boolean transform(JavaClass clazz) {
        return false;
    }

    public void finish() {
        System.out.println("Finished Recording non static methods and fields");
    }
}

ftw

@ruler wrote:

the speed of jni is not as bad as some of you think. However i liked using flat files bc i did not have to write a scar .dll . I also thought of accessing the registry thur the scar intermessage. I thought using the registry would be slower then files.

item.title: A possible base for a bot
item.dc:creator: @regecks1 regecks`
item.description:
@regecks1 wrote:

I have used shared memory before: polling JNI when you want to check if there is data is very slow, however, you can also use JNI to fire on any listeners when shared memory is changed … depends how you implement it.

Read full topic
item.source: A possible base for a bot

item.title: A possible base for a bot
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

ruler:

All mouse/key functions etc were done on the java side. We used text files to get input from scar and would paint images as responses for scar to read. For scar to get the bitmap, cruel implemented his client as a scar plugin and overload’s scars bitmap.

Did you try communicating with shared memory? I would think that reading and writing would be much more efficient and speedy to RAM than to the harddrive. Although the speed of JNI must also be taken into account…

Read full topic

item.title: A possible base for a bot
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote=“Krichevskoy, post:16, topic:59685”][quote author=ruler link=topic=85661.msg921289#msg921289 date=1171980765]

javaagent ftl, but gj frank and krypton

I don’t think you know what you’re talking about. A java agent solution gives you everything you need and more. Not only does it ease class file instrumentation by hand feeding you the data, it allows you to instrument those class files right off the Jagex website, I can’t stress enough how important this is.

The problem with this community is that most of you are stuck doing things the old fashioned way such as running loader + client locally (a good solution if done properly). The new solutions people try to introduce get shut down even if they are more efficient and less detectable.

Some of us like it. I personally haven’t had time to play with Instrumentation, but I’ve introduced SRL to the idea. It seems like the ideal solution for grabbing information from an otherwise unchanged client (perfect SCAR hybrid doctrine).

Also, with a robust updater it would eliminate a great deal of inconvenience involved with handling a bot program.

this had already been done about 8 months ago using UBI and Cruel’s client and modified SRL running on scar. The issue came to be scar’s performance.
[/quote]

I’d be interested in seeing that - how did you communicate between SCAR and the client? That’s the problem I have with previous hybrid designs, extremely inefficient or cumbersome polling methods.[/quote]
All mouse/key functions etc were done on the java side. We used text files to get input from scar and would paint images as responses for scar to read. For scar to get the bitmap, cruel implemented his client as a scar plugin and overload’s scars bitmap.

Read full topic

[quote=“ruler, post:15, topic:59685”][quote author=Krichevskoy link=topic=85661.msg920474#msg920474 date=1171958121]

javaagent ftl, but gj frank and krypton

I don’t think you know what you’re talking about. A java agent solution gives you everything you need and more. Not only does it ease class file instrumentation by hand feeding you the data, it allows you to instrument those class files right off the Jagex website, I can’t stress enough how important this is.

The problem with this community is that most of you are stuck doing things the old fashioned way such as running loader + client locally (a good solution if done properly). The new solutions people try to introduce get shut down even if they are more efficient and less detectable.

Some of us like it. I personally haven’t had time to play with Instrumentation, but I’ve introduced SRL to the idea. It seems like the ideal solution for grabbing information from an otherwise unchanged client (perfect SCAR hybrid doctrine).

Also, with a robust updater it would eliminate a great deal of inconvenience involved with handling a bot program.
[/quote]
this had already been done about 8 months ago using UBI and Cruel’s client and modified SRL running on scar. The issue came to be scar’s performance.[/quote]

I’d be interested in seeing that - how did you communicate between SCAR and the client? That’s the problem I have with previous hybrid designs, extremely inefficient or cumbersome polling methods.
